awd_titl_txt: International Collaboration in Chemistry: First Principles Multi-Lattice Kinetic Monte Carlo Simulations of NOx Storage Reduction Catalysts
awd_abstract_narration:
Professor Randall Meyer of the University of Illinois at Chicago is supported by the Chemical Catalysis Program in the Division of Chemistry and the Office of International Science and Engineering to conduct research in collaboration with Professor Karsten Reuter of the Technical University of Munich to develop an integrated multi-scale theoretical approach combining DFT and a multi-lattice first-principles kinetic Monte Carlo (kMC) approach to gain a fundamental understanding of the surface reaction chemistry of exhaust catalysts operating under cycling conditions between oxidizing and reducing environments.   The specific application to be investigated is the PdO (101)/Pd (100) surface for the NOx storage reduction (NSR) catalyst system.  Material-specific and time-dependent simulation tools that can follow the evolution of the system over the macroscopic time-scales of NSR cycles, while simultaneously accounting for the atomic-scale site heterogeneity and spatial distributions at the evolving surface, will be developed. Professort Reuter is funded by the German funding agency, the DFG. 

The ability to follow the evolution of surface morphology with atomic-level resolution and at the timescale of a cycle of the exhaust system operation is important from a fundamental catalysis point of view.  The proposed methodology is likely to impact simulations of other heterogeneous catalytic systems as well. It will also have important practical applications, such as in automotive vehicles fuel economy.  Students will be trained in computational catalysis and will be exposed to an international research experience with opportunities to network with researchers in Germany through a student exchange plan.

por.por_cntn:
The primary focus of this proposal was the use of kinetic Monte Carlo (kMC) methods to understand the cycling behavior in NOx Storage Reduction (NSR) catalysts.  kMC is a method of coarse graining time such that dynamic simulations of atomistic processes can be performed with time scales that are on the order of realistic industrial applications. The basic premise is that for a given system a number of different types of events can occur on an atomic scale. Molecules may adsorb or desorb to or form a catalytic surface; Molecules may diffuse across the surface; Molecules may undergo reactions with neighboring molecules on the surface. Each one of these potential processes can be described with a rate. kMC sums all of these rates to create a total rate for the system and then selects the process to be performed by choosing a random number that selects the individual process according to its relative probability. The system is then updated to its new configuration and a new random number is generated to repeat the process. By examining thousands (often millions) of events, the steady state condition of the catalytic surface can be determined and macroscopic rates can be derived for comparison with experiment. To date, kMC has been applied to systems with fixed lattices for relatively simple chemistries. The goal of the current work was to expand kMC to variable lattices using the expertise of our partner in Germany, Prof. Karsten Reuter and to take on the case of NSR catalysis.

The primary result that stemmed from this work was the identification of regions of instability between the metal and metal oxide surface for Pd catalysts in the NSR environment. These regions of instability arise from the hysteresis which can occur as one moves from a reducing condition where the metal is favored to an oxidizing condition where the oxide is favored. In these dynamic cases, the kinetics, rather than the thermodynamics determine the surface termination. In the case of CO oxidation, this region of instability is fairly narrow. However, in NO oxidation it is much larger with respect to the temperature/pressure range over which the thermodynamically preferred surface may not be observed. For hydrogen oxidation, this bistability region further expands. It is speculated that the large metastability region for H2 oxidation exists due to the weak binding of H2 on the surface. In contrast to NO and CO oxidation, the phase diagram of H2 oxidation is dominated by surfaces involving the presence of a surface intermediate, OH. Under typical reaction conditions, the favored surface termination will be a hydroxylated monolayer oxide film. This result seems to be in agreement with previous experimental results of Pd methane oxidation catalysts.

This work demonstrates the complexity that can be observed even for a simple system with a few different types of adsorbates. An interplay will exist between kinetics and thermodynamics that will dictate the performance of the catalyst. In addition, some of the critical calculations described in this work were performed by undergraduate researchers through REU supplements and by students from the Illinois Math and Science Academy in Aurora through their Student Inquiry and Research program.
